Award.AwardTitle: Cell distribution and segregation phenomena in blood flow: biomechanical aspects and impacts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1436082

This project will use numerical methods and computer simulation to examine blood flow in the vascular system and in extracorporeal channels, including microfluidic devices that process blood for diagnostic purposes. The project will focus on analyzing and predicting the migration of cells during flow. Red blood cells tend to migrate toward the center of a vessel or channel, while white blood cells and platelets are displaced toward vessel or channel walls. The project will investigate how cell migration is affected by the geometry of the vessel cross-section, hematocrit, flow rate through the vessel, and interactions among the cells. In addition, the proposal will consider the effects of small amount of polymers added to the blood. These polymers are known to reduce energy losses in turbulent flow, but recent evidence suggests they may also affect laminar blood flow in ways that have physiological benefits.

A computational and mathematical framework will be developed for predicting migration of blood cells during flow through a vessel. Red blood cell margination and the formation of cell free layers at the vessel walls will be examined for flow geometries characteristic of the circulation and microfluidic devices. The role of long-chain drag reducing polymers will be examined to resolve the mechanism by which they affect margination and the development of a cell free layer. The results of the computer simulations will be compared with experiments carried out by the investigator?s colleagues. The results will improve our understanding of the biomechanical aspects of various hematological disorders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit


The dynamics and transport of blood cells in the circulation are complex. Red blood cells (RBCs) migrate toward the center of a blood vessel leaving an RBC-depleted cell-free layer (CFL) near vessel walls, while white blood cells (WBCs) and platelets tend to reside in these layers, a phenomenon called margination. These segregation phenomena have important consequences in health and disease, treatments such as vascular drug delivery, and microfluidic approaches to modeling phenomena such as thrombosis and various "blood-on-a-chip'' microfluidic approaches to diagnostics.  We have developed a first-principles theory for CFL formation and margination based on the collision dynamics and wall-induced migration of deformable particles in flow. Thus theory excellent agreement with experiments. Furthermore, we have found that a master curve that allows a wide variety of cell-free layer thickness results for different channel sizes, flow rates and concentrations to collapse onto a single curve with only one free parameter.  We have performed a detailed computational study of how shape affects margination in suspensions of fluid-filled deformable capsules. The computational results are compared with the analytical theory and excellent agreement is found. Furthermore, we have begun extending our computational methods to allow for general flow geometries including contraction/expansions and bifurcations.

Broader Impacts

The fundamental advances made under this grant have substantial implications for a range of blood flow phenomena.  In collaboration with the research group of Wilbur Lam, the PI's group has shown that certain drugs, have a biomechanical role with regard to the distribution of white blood cells in the bloodstream.  This work was published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences. More recently, the focus of this collaboration has shifted to sickle cell disease, where the research performed here has implications for understanding and potentially treatment of the disease. We have examined the hypothesis that some of the manifestations of sickle cell disease, such as chronic dysfunction of the endothelial cells lining the blood vessel and increased propensity of SCD patients to suffer stroke, are related to margination of the stiffer ISCs to blood vessel walls and subsequent interactions with the endothelial cells.  Our simulations support this hypothesis -- ISCs exhibit substantial margination and thereby are in frequent contact with the endothelium, in contrast to  healthy red blood cells, which are set off from the endothelium by the cell-free layer. 


With regard to educational impacts, the principal investigator of this grant has co-developed a undergraduate engineering course ``Chemical Engineering in the Community'' that he continues to develope and participate in. In this course, undergraduate students develop age-appropriate fluid-mechanics-based educational activities for K-12 kids and go to various venues including the Boys and Girls Club of Dane County and the Wisconsin Science Festivla, and local schools, to perform the activities with the kids. This project has run two times over the duration of this grant and will continue in future semesters.

Modified by: Michael D Graham
